row.Title: Wine Vessel (Jue) from Tomb of Fu Hao
row.Description: Description: This wine vessel was found in the tomb of Fu Hao, the consort of Wu Ding (the 23rd Emperor of the Shang Dynasty). The earliest Chinese bronzes were made by the method known as piece-mold casting—as opposed to the lost-wax method, which was used in all other Bronze Age cultures. In piece-mold casting, a model is made of the object to be cast, and a clay mold taken of the model. The mold is then cut in sections to release the model, and the sections are reassembled after firing to form the mold for casting. If the object to be cast is a vessel, a core has to be placed inside the mold to provide the vessel’s cavity. | Location created: Henan Sheng, China | Date created: c.1300-1030 BCE | Medium: Bronze | Measurements: h. 66.8 cm
row.Subject: Bronzes--China | Grave goods
row.Genre: Bronze Age | bronzes (visual works) | ceremonial vessels | Anyang (Shang style)
row.Century: 13th century BCD | 12th century BCE | 11th century BCE

row.Title: Bronze Owl-Shaped Zun from Tomb of Fu Hao
row.Description: Description: This wine vessel (zun or tsun) was found in the tomb of Fu Hao, the consort of Wu Ding (the 23rd Emperor of the Shang Dynasty). The vessel is inscribed with her name. Used in religious ceremonies to hold wine, the vessel has a wide lip to facilitate pouring. The owl-like creature stands on two legs; a down-turned tail forms the third leg. The back of the head is a removable lid with a miniature bird and dragons as knobs. | Location created: Henan Sheng, China | Date created: c.1300-1030 BCE | Current location: Institute of Archeology, Beijing | Medium: Bronze | Measurements: h. 45.9 cm
row.Subject: Bronzes--China | Grave goods | Owls in art
row.Genre: Bronze Age | bronzes (visual works) | ceremonial vessels | Anyang (Shang style)
row.Century: 13th century BCD | 12th century BCE | 11th century BCE

row.Title: Fittings in Form of Tigers
row.Description: Description: This tiger-shaped bronze with deep cavities is extremely heavy and must have been made as supports for an unknown purpose, perhaps to raise a group of musical instruments or a special piece of furniture. Whatever the intended function, the form was obviously inspired by real tigers. The low-slung body is elongated, with powerful legs and a long, coiled tail. Its blocky, ferocious head has erect ears and dots that represent whisker follicles. The flank, lower legs, and tail are covered with stripes to evoke the patterns on the live animal. On second look, however, the stiff forms are boxy and abstract, hovering between natural and decorative impulses. Signaling an early phase in Chinese representational sculpture, the three-dimensional image was approached as an assemblage of flat views of sides, front, back, and top. According to a note received when these objects were acquired in 1935 by the Freer Galleries, objects such as this were unearthed in 1923 at Baoji in Shaanxi province in the hereditary homeland of the Zhou dynasty rulers. | Date created: c.900-850 BCE | Current location: Freer Gallery of Art | Medium: Bronze | Measurements: l. 75.2 cmm h, 25.2 cm
row.Subject: Bronzes--China | Tigers in art
row.Genre: Bronze Age | bronzes (visual works)

row.Title: Bronze acrobat Tong ren
row.Description: Description: Despite its asymmetric pose, this figure achives a dynamic equilibrium in its stance that is appropriate to an acrobat. The tension of balancing is conveyed through the flexed arms and legs. The figure's costume is minutely observed. The man wears a short robe secured around the waist by a belt from which hangs a dagger.The fact that he wears trousers and boots, items of dress first introduced into China around the fifth century BC, may mean that he representss a northern nomad rather than a Han chinese. | Date created: 5th-4th c. BCE | Medium: Bronze | Measurements: 10.2 cm
row.Subject: Bronzes--China
row.Genre: Bronze Age | bronzes (visual works) | Zhou (culture) | figurine

row.Title: Tomb of Ch'in Shih-Huang-Ti: Infantry Officer
row.Alternative_Title: Life-size warrior from the tomb complex of Qin Shihuangdi | Terracotta soldier | Ceramic soldier
row.Description: Description: This is one of the terra-cotta soldiers from the tomb of Emperor Ch'in (Qin), this figure was found in Pit II in the tomb complex. The Terracotta Army or the "Terracotta Warriors and Horses" is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210-209 BCE and whose purpose was to protect the emperor in his afterlife. The figures vary in height according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots and horses. Estimates from 2007 were that the three pits containing the Terracotta Army held more than 8,000 soldiers (such as this soldier shown), 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which remained buried in the pits nearby Qin Shi Huang's mausoleum. | Location created: The masoleum of Emperor Shihuangdi, Lintong, Shaanxi Sheng (China) | Date created: c. 210 BCE ) | Medium: Terracotta earthenware | Measurements: 70 in
row.Subject: Terra-cotta figurines--China | Grave goods
row.Genre: Qin (culture or period) | mausoleums | terracottas (sculptural works) | funerary art

row.Title: Tomb of Ch'in Shih-Huang-Ti: archer with armor
row.Alternative_Title: Life-size warrior from the tomb complex of Qin Shihuangdi | Terracotta soldier | Ceramic soldier
row.Description: Description: This is one of the terra-cotta soldiers from the tomb of Emperor Ch'in (Qin), this figure was found in Pit II in the tomb complex. The Terracotta Army or the "Terracotta Warriors and Horses" is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210-209 BCE and whose purpose was to protect the emperor in his afterlife. The figures vary in height according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots and horses. Estimates from 2007 were that the three pits containing the Terracotta Army held more than 8,000 soldiers (such as this soldier shown), 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which remained buried in the pits nearby Qin Shi Huang's mausoleum. | Location created: The masoleum of Emperor Shihuangdi, Lintong, Shaanxi Sheng (China) | Date created: c. 210 BCE ) | Current location: X | Medium: Terracotta earthenware

row.Title: Hu with bird-script design
row.Alternative_Title: Tomb of Liu Sheng | Wine vessel with bird-script design
row.Description: Description: This is a wine vessel (hu) with a bird-script design, created during the early Han dynasty. This vessel was found in the tomb of Prince Liu Sheng in Mancheng, Heibei province. | Location created: Mancheng, Hebei Province (China) | Date created: c. 113 BCE | Medium: Bronze with gold and silver inlay | Measurements: 44.2 cm
row.Subject: Bronzes--China | Grave goods
row.Genre: Western Han | bronzes (visual works) | funerary vessels

row.Title: Tales from History and Legends: Lintel and Pediment of a Tomb
row.Alternative_Title: Tales from History and Legends: Painted Tile from Tympanum of Tomb near Luoyang, Henan
row.Description: Description: This painted pediment and lintel comes from a tomb in the village of Balitai, near Luoyang, Henan (China). The painting depicts several narrative sequences. | Location created: Luoyang, Henan | Date created: Late 1st century BCE | Current location: Boston Museum of Fine Arts | Medium: Earthenware hollow tiles of a tomb and lintel pediment; ink and color on a whitened ground | Measurements: 73.3 x 240.7 cm (28 7/8 x 94 3/4 in.)
row.Subject: Tombs--China | Funeral rites and ceremonies | Sepuchral monuments
row.Genre: paintings (visual works) | Western Han | funerary structures | door heads

row.Title: Two Han Gentlemen: painted ceramic tile
row.Alternative_Title: Gentlemen in conversation, Eastern Han Dynasty | Tales from History and Legends: Painted Tile from Tympanum of Tomb near Luoyang, Hena
row.Description: Description: This is a detail from "Tales from History and Legends: Lintel and Pediment of a Tomb," found in a tomb near Luoyang, Henan. In this scene, we see two Han-period men engaged in conversation. | Location created: Luoyang, Henan | Date created: Late 1st century BCE | Current location: Boston Museum of Fine Arts | Medium: Earthenware hollow tiles of a tomb and lintel pediment; ink and color on a whitened ground
row.Subject: Sepuchral monuments | Painting--China
row.Genre: paintings (visual works) | Western Han | funerary structures | door heads

row.Title: Cave 20 at Yungang (detail of Seated Buddha)
row.Description: Description: This is a detail of the robes of the colossal seated Buddha at Yungang. The caves were constructed under the Northern Wei imperial sponsorship near Datong in present-day Shanxi Province, and were decorated with sculptural images made after Indian models, such as this monumental seated Buddha from Cave 20. We can see from the holes that structural additions once existed. These cave temples and sculptures were proposed under the monk Tanyao. | Location created: Datong, Shanxi province, China | Date created: c. 471-499 CE | Current location: Datong, Shanxi province, China | Medium: Sandstone with pigment
row.Subject: Buddhist sculpture--China | Stone carving
row.Genre: Han (Chinese, culture, style, period) | Mahayana | rock-cut sculpture | Six Dynasties | Northern Wei (culture, style, and period)

row.Title: Cave 20 at Yungang (detail of Smaller Buddha)
row.Description: Description: This is a detail of the Smaller Buddha, which stands to the proper left of the Colossal Buddha (or Colossal Shakyamuni) in Cave 20 at Yungang. The caves were constructed under the Northern Wei imperial sponsorship near Datong in present-day Shanxi Province, and were decorated with sculptural images made after Indian models. These cave temples and sculptures were proposed under the monk Tanyao. | Location created: Datong, Shanxi province, China | Date created: c. 471-499 CE | Current location: Datong, Shanxi province, China | Medium: Sandstone with pigment
row.Subject: Buddhist sculpture--China | Stone carving
row.Genre: Han (Chinese, culture, style, period) | Mahayana | rock-cut sculpture | Six Dynasties | Northern Wei (culture, style, and period)

row.Title: Cave 6 at Yungang
row.Alternative_Title: Yungang shiku: #6 ku: Fuxin | Yun-kang shih k' (Temple) | Yungang grottoes
row.Description: Description: This is located in a the temple in Cave 6 of the Yungang Grottoes (or Yungang Caves), on the west side of the west wall's top level. Cave 6 is classified as part of the Middle Period of the Yungang Grottoes, and characterized by its more complex carvings. Buddha makes the fearlessness hand gesture, or abhaya mudra. A mandorla (an almond shaped halo extending around his body) indicates his divinity. The flames suggest the Buddha's radiating energy and tiny images of the Buddha recall the miracle at Shravasti, in which Shakyamuni appeared to replicate his body 1000 times in order to illustrate the principle that existence is only an illusion. | Location created: Datong, Shanxi province, China | Date created: c. 471-499 CE | Current location: Datong, Shanxi province, China | Medium: Sandstone with pigment
row.Subject: Buddhist sculpture--China | Stone carving
row.Genre: Han (Chinese, culture, style, period) | Mahayana | rock-cut sculpture | Six Dynasties | Northern Wei (culture, style, and period)

row.Title: Sculpture of Amitabha
row.Description: Description: This is a gilt bronze altar depicting Amitabha Buddha, flanked by four bodhisattva. Two dogs are seen near the bottom; one dog is snarling and the other appears docile. | Location created: Bali, Xi'an, Shaanxi province | Date created: c. 557-581 CE | Medium: Gilt bronze | Measurements: 16 x 9.5 x 9.6 in
row.Subject: Buddhist sculpture--China | Buddhist altars | Bronze sculpture
row.Genre: Sui | portable altarpieces | bodhisattvas | Mahayana

row.Title: Taima Mandala
row.Description: Description: This mandala represents Amida Buddha's Western Paradise or Pure Land, where the souls of fervent believers are reborn to continue their quest for spiritual enlightenment free from the difficulties associated with life on earth. In the center, Amida sits beneath a jeweled canopy surrounded by a host of other deities and worshippers. His splendid palaces are in the background and the sky is filled with flying deities and heavenly musicians. The palaces are based on eighth-century Chinese palaces. Amida faces a pond where the souls of the deceased are reborn on lotus blossoms. According to tradition, the first Japanese mandala of Amida's paradise was painted in the eighth century and has been preserved in the collection of Taima-dera temple near Nara. As worship of Amida became increasingly popular in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, numerous copies were produced. Accordingly, this painting and others like it are referred to as Taima Mandala. | Location created: Japan | Date created: c. 14th century CE | Current location: The Minnesota Insitute of Arts | Medium: Ink, color, gold, and cut gold leaf (kirikane) on silk | Measurements: 50.5 x 46 in
row.Subject: Buddhist art | Mandala
row.Genre: paintings (visual works) | mandalas

row.Title: Guanyin, Bodhisattva of Compassion
row.Description: Description: Guanyin (also known as Avalokiteshvara in Sanskrit) is the Bodhisattva of Compassion. As a bodhisattva, Guanyin has forgone Buddhahood to help other sentient beings be free of suffering before enlightenment. In this sculpture of the Guanyin bodhisattva, we see the figure adorned with elaborate necklaces, signaling royality, and standing atop the double lotus, symbolizing purity. | Location created: China | Date created: c. 580 CE | Current location: Boston Museum of Fine Arts | Medium: Limestone with traces of polychrome and gilding | Measurements: 249 x 71 x 71 cm (98 1/16 x 27 15/16 x 27 15/16 in)
row.Subject: Buddhist sculpture--China | Stone carving
row.Genre: Sui | Northern Zhou (culture, style, and period) | bodhisattvas | Mahayana

row.Title: Facial detail of Guanyin, Bodhisattva of Compassion
row.Description: Description: This is a detail of the sculpture, Guanyin, Bodhisattva of Compassion. In this detail, we see the elongated earlobes with heavy earrings, and a miniature image of Buddha framed by a flaming mandorla atop the bodhisattva's headdress. | Location created: China | Date created: c. 580 CE | Current location: Boston Museum of Fine Arts | Medium: Limestone with traces of polychrome and gilding | Measurements: 249 x 71 x 71 cm (98 1/16 x 27 15/16 x 27 15/16 in)
row.Subject: Buddhist sculpture--China | Stone carving
row.Genre: Sui | Northern Zhou (culture, style, and period) | bodhisattvas | Mahayana

row.Title: Admonitions of the Court Instructress to the Palace Ladies (detail)
row.Alternative_Title: Admonitions scroll | The Rejection Scene | Tenth scene
row.Creator: Kaizhi, Gu, 344-405
row.Description: Description: Though this is a detail of a single scene, the format of this painting is a handscroll-- a horizontally organized composition on paper or silk, designed to be gradually unrolled and viewed from right to left. This scroll is a visualization of Zhang Hua's (232-300) poem of the same title. The images, such as this detail, teach the proper behavior of imperial consorts and concubines. Images, such as this, represent both historical figures and idealized scenes that demonstrate the importance of virtue, cultivation of character, trust, and family. This particular scene shows the emporer turning away from his consort, his hand raised in a gesture of rejection. | Location created: China | Date created: c. 5th - 8th century CE | Current location: British Museum, London | Medium: Handscroll, ink and color on silk | Measurements: 9 5/8 x 135 3/5 in (24.3 x 343.7 cm)
row.Subject: Painting--China
row.Genre: Six dynasties | handscrolls | paintings (visual works)

row.Title: Admonitions of the Court Instructress to the Palace Ladies (detail)
row.Alternative_Title: Admonitions scroll | The toilette scene | Seventh scene
row.Creator: Kaizhi, Gu, 344-405
row.Description: Description: Though this is a detail of a single scene, the format of this painting is a handscroll-- a horizontally organized composition on paper or silk, designed to be gradually unrolled and viewed from right to left. This scroll is a visualization of Zhang Hua's (232-300) poem of the same title. The images, such as this detail, teach the proper behavior of imperial consorts and concubines. Images, such as this, represent both historical figures and idealized scenes that demonstrate the importance of virtue, cultivation of character, trust, and family. This particular scene shows the palace ladies at their toilette. The focus of the scene is on a lady sitting in front of a bronze mirror, with a set of nested lacquer boxes laid out to the side. The the right, another lady (facing away from the viewer) looking into a mirror held in her hand. The two mirrors in this scene perhaps indicate reflections of the figures' inner nature as much as their external appearence. | Location created: China | Date created: c. 5th - 8th century CE | Current location: British Museum, London | Medium: Handscroll, ink and color on silk | Measurements: 9 5/8 x 135 3/5 in (24.3 x 343.7 cm)
row.Subject: Painting--China
row.Genre: Six dynasties | handscrolls | paintings (visual works)

row.Title: Nymph of the Luo River (copy)
row.Creator: Kaizhi, Gu, 344-405
row.Description: Description: This is a later copy of a painted handscroll attributed to Gu Kaizhi (c. 345-406 CE). This scroll visualizes the prose-poem, Luoshen fu, by poet Cao Zhi. In this detail, we see Cao Shi sitting by the Luo River, a tributary of the Yellow River. The scroll represents early landscape painting in Chinese art history. | Location created: China | Date created: c. mid-12th-mid-13th century CE | Current location: Freer Gallery of Art | Medium: Handscroll, paint on silk | Measurements: 24 x 130 cm
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Six dynasties | handscrolls | paintings (visual works)

row.Title: Mountain Landscape
row.Creator: Dong, Yuan, -962
row.Description: Description: Landscape emerged as a dominent genre in Chinese painting, and the painters of the Southern Tang and Northern Song dynasties that specialized in it would retrospectively be heralded as the originators of pictorial styles that later artists employed. Landscape paintings, such as this by Dong Yuan, indicate both natural observation and stylistic exaggeration in the created composition. This landscape painting specifically shows the rounded mountains of Jiangnan, the region of China south of the Yangzi River that formed the domain of the Southern Tang state. | Date created: c. 950 CE | Medium: Hanging scroll, ink and color on silk | Measurements: 156 x 160 cm
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Tang (Chinese culture, style, period) | landscapes (representations) | paintings (visual works) | hanging scrolls | Dong-Ju

row.Title: Travelers Amid Mountains and Streams
row.Creator: Fan, Kuan, approximately 956-approximately 1026
row.Description: Description: This large hanging scroll is Fan Kuan's best known work and a seminal painting of the Northern Song school. It establishes an ideal in monumental landscape painting to which later painters were to return time and again for inspiration. The painting's style also includes conventions dating back to the Tang Dynasty. The classic Chinese perspective of three planes is evident - near, middle (represented by water and mist), and far. However, unlike earlier examples of Chinese landscape art, the grandeur of nature is the main theme, rather than merely providing a backdrop. | Current location: National Palace Museum, Taipei | Medium: Ink and color on silk | Measurements: 81.22 x 40. 67 in
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Northern Song | landscapes (representations) | hanging scrolls | Taoism

row.Title: Early Spring
row.Creator: Guo, Xi, active 11th century
row.Description: Description: A masterpiece of the Northern Song monumental landscape painting tradition, Early Spring is a rare example of an early painting executed by a court professional who signed and dated his work. The work demonstrates Guo Xi's innovative techniques for producing multiple perspectives, which he called "the angle of totality." The brushwork registers infinite variations of pressure and ink; the silhouette of the rocks and boulders are delineated with a heavy touch, the foggy trees with a light one. The artist also shows a concern with the idea of 'temporarily,' evident in the representation of the eroding landscape and specific seasonal moment. | Location created: National Palace Museum, Taipei | Date created: 1072 CE | Medium: Ink and color on silk | Measurements: 158.3 x 108.1 cm
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Northern Song | landscapes (representations) | hanging scrolls | Confucianism

row.Title: Cloudy Mountains
row.Creator: Mi, Youren, 1086-1165
row.Description: Description: The son of Mi Fu (1052–1107), Mi Youren was an accomplished scholar-artist, calligrapher, and the leading connoisseur of his time, often acting as the authenticator of ancient paintings for the emperor. He rose to the position of vice president of the Board of War. The simplified, blurry mountain forms, which Mi Youren inherited from his father (there is no longer any reliable example of the older Mi's painted work), represent a significant break from the detailed Northern Song landscape styles. Created with wet ink dots (called "Mi-family style") this style of landscape painting is the immediated predecessor of the evocative ink-wash landscape style of the later Southern Song period. Referred to by scholar-artists as "ink play," the style suggests the importance of the painter's psychological expression, thereby raising the status of painting to that of poetry and calligraphy. Mi Youren was an important figure in Southern Song literati painting. | Date created: 1130 CE | Current location: The Cleveland Museum of Art | Medium: Handscroll, ink and color on silk | Measurements: Image: 43.70 x 192.60 cm (17 3/16 x 75 13/16 inches); Overall: 45.50 x 646.80 cm (17 7/8 x 254 5/8 inches)
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Southern Song | landscapes (representations) | handscrolls l paintings (visual works) | Literati (painters)

row.Title: Scholar viewing a waterfall
row.Creator: Ma, Yuan, active 12th century-13th century
row.Description: Description: Court painter Ma Yuan, a fourth-generation member of a family of painters, was a leading artist at the Southern Song painting academy in Hangzhou. Along with Xia Gui, Ma Yuan originated the Ma-Xia style of landscape painting. In this album leaf, which shows a gentleman in a gardenlike setting, the jagged rhythms of the pine tree and garden contrast with the quiet mood of the scholar, who gazes pensively into the bubbling rapids of the cascade. This image demonstrates one-corner composition, heavily weighted toward the bottom left. It also shows a sense of atmosphere through ink wash, particularly noticable in the silhouette of the distant waterfall. | Location created: Hangzhou, China | Date created: c. late-12th - early-13th centuries | Current location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art | Medium: Album leaf; ink and colors on silk | Measurements: 9 7/8 x 10 1/4 in. (25.1 x 26 cm)
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Southern Song | landscapes (representations) | paintings (visual works) | Ma-Xia

row.Title: Twelve Views of a Landscape (detail 1)
row.Creator: Xia, Gui, active 1190-1224
row.Description: Description: Xia Gui was part of the Ma-Xia School of landscape painting. 'Twelve Views of Landscape' once included 12 scenes, but only the last four survive on Xia's original scroll. An empress's single-dragon seal appears in red below each of the titles, suggesting that the calligrapher could be Empress Yang Meizi. The titles of each scene allude to poetry on the 'Eight Views of Xiao and Xiang Rivers,' a theme concerning withdrawl of society that originated with the Northern Song literati. The painting includes motifs familiar from the associated pictorial tradition. As this detail shows, Xia utilized ax-cut strokes and subtle washes of ink to achieve his landscape representation. | Date created: c. 1210 CE | Current location: Nelson Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City | Medium: Handscroll, ink on silk | Measurements: 11 x 90 1/2 in (28 x 230 cm)
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Southern Song | landscapes (representations) | paintings (visual works) | Ma-Xia

row.Title: Twelve Views of a Landscape (detail 3)
row.Creator: Xia, Gui, active 1190-1224
row.Description: Description: Xia Gui was part of the Ma-Xia School of landscape painting. 'Twelve Views of Landscape' once included 12 scenes, but only the last four survive on Xia's original scroll. An empress's single-dragon seal appears in red below each of the titles, suggesting that the calligrapher could be Empress Yang Meizi. The titles of each scene allude to poetry on the 'Eight Views of Xiao and Xiang Rivers,' a theme concerning withdrawl of society that originated with the Northern Song literati. The painting includes motifs familiar from the associated pictorial tradition. As this detail shows, Xia utilized ax-cut strokes and subtle washes of ink to achieve his landscape representation. | Date created: c. 1210 CE | Current location: Nelson Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City | Medium: Handscroll, ink on silk | Measurements: 11 x 90 1/2 in (28 x 230 cm)
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Southern Song | landscapes (representations) | handscrolls | paintings (visual works) | Ma-Xia

row.Title: Twelve Views of a Landscape (detail)
row.Creator: Xia, Gui, active 1190-1224
row.Description: Description: Xia Gui was part of the Ma-Xia School of landscape painting. 'Twelve Views of Landscape' once included 12 scenes, but only the last four survive on Xia's original scroll. An empress's single-dragon seal appears in red below each of the titles, suggesting that the calligrapher could be Empress Yang Meizi. The titles of each scene allude to poetry on the 'Eight Views of Xiao and Xiang Rivers,' a theme concerning withdrawl of society that originated with the Northern Song literati. The painting includes motifs familiar from the associated pictorial tradition. As this detail shows, Xia utilized ax-cut strokes and subtle washes of ink to achieve his landscape representation. | Date created: c. 1210 CE | Current location: Nelson Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City | Medium: Handscroll, ink on silk | Measurements: 11 x 90 1/2 in (28 x 230 cm)
row.Subject: Painting--China | Landscape painting, Chinese
row.Genre: Southern Song | landscapes (representations) | handscrolls | paintings (visual works) | Ma-Xia
